description: The FHS segment is used to head a file (group of batches) as defined in Section 2.10.3, "HL7 batch protocol".

fields.name: File Field Separator
fields.description: This field has the same definition as the corresponding field in the MSH segment.

fields.name: File Encoding Characters
fields.description: This field has the same definition as the corresponding field in the MSH segment.

fields.name: File Sending Application
fields.description: This field has the same definition as the corresponding field in the MSH segment.

fields.name: Namespace Id
fields.description:
The local coded item for the entity. The component intentionally remains associated with the IS data type in v 2.7.

User-defined Table 0300 - Namespace ID is used as the HL7 identifier for the user-defined table of values for this component. 

Note: When the HD is used in a given segment (either as a field or as a component of another data type) this table may be re-defined (given a different user-defined table number and name) by the technical committee responsible for that segment.

fields.name: Universal Id
fields.description: The HD’s second component, <universal ID> (UID), is a string formatted according to the scheme defined by the third component, <universal ID type> (UID type). The UID is intended to be unique over time within the UID type. It is rigorously defined. Each UID must belong to one of the specifically enumerated schemes for constructing UIDs (defined by the UID type). The UID (second component) must follow the syntactic rules of the particular universal identifier scheme (defined by the third component). Note that these syntactic rules are not defined within HL7 but are defined by the rules of the particular universal identifier scheme (defined by the third component).

fields.name: Universal Id Type
fields.dataTypeName: Coded Value For Hl7 Defined Tables
fields.description: The third component governs the interpretation of the second component of the HD. If the third component is a known UID refer to HL7 Table 0301 - Universal ID type for valid values, then the second component is a universal ID of that type.

fields.name: File Sending Facility
fields.description: This field has the same definition as the corresponding field in the MSH segment.

fields.name: File Creation Date/Time
fields.description: This field has the same definition as the corresponding field in the MSH segment.

fields.name: File Security
fields.description: This field has the same definition as the corresponding field in the MSH segment.

fields.name: File Name/Id
fields.description: This field can be used by the application processing file. Its use is not further specified.

fields.name: File Header Comment
fields.description: This field contains the free text field, the use of which is not further specified.

fields.name: File Control Id
fields.description: This field is used to identify a particular file uniquely. It can be echoed back in FHS-12-reference file control ID.

fields.name: Reference File Control Id
fields.description: This field contains the value of FHS-11-file control ID when this file was originally transmitted. Not present if this file is being transmitted for the first time.

fields.name: File Sending Network Address
fields.description: Identifier of the network location the message was transmitted from. Identified by an OID or text string (e.g., URI). The reader is referred to the "Report from the Joint W3C/IETF URI Planning Interest Group: Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs), URLs, and Uniform Resource Names (URNs): Clarifications and Recommendations".

fields.name: Namespace Id
fields.description:

Note: When the HD is used in a given segment (either as a field or as a component of another data type) this table may be re-defined (given a different user-defined table number and name) by the technical committee responsible for that segment.

fields.name: Universal Id
fields.description: The HD’s second component, <universal ID> (UID), is a string formatted according to the scheme defined by the third component, <universal ID type> (UID type). The UID is intended to be unique over time within the UID type. It is rigorously defined. Each UID must belong to one of the specifically enumerated schemes for constructing UIDs (defined by the UID type). The UID (second component) must follow the syntactic rules of the particular universal identifier scheme (defined by the third component). fields.name: Universal Id Type
fields.dataTypeName: Coded Value For Hl7 Defined Tables

fields.name: File Receiving Network Address
fields.description:
Identifier of the network location the message was transmitted to. Identified by an OID or text string. (e.g., URL).

This is analogous with the Sending Network Address, however in the receiving role.

This field should only be populated when the underlying communication protocol does not support identification receiving network locations.
